[[235]](#cite_note-:22-235) Sri Lanka[ [edit](/w/index.php?title=Organic_farming&action=edit§ion=46)] As was the case with most countries, Sri Lanka made the transition away from organic farming upon the arrival of the Green Revolution, whereupon it started depending more on chemical fertilizers. This became a highly popularized method when the nation started offering subsidies on the import of artificial fertilizers to increase rice paddy production, and to incentivize farmers to switch from growing traditional varieties into using high yielding varieties (HYVs). [[236]](#cite_note-236) This was especially true for young farmers who saw short-term economic profit as more sustainable to their wellbeing, compared to the long term drawbacks to the environment. [[237]](#cite_note-237) However, due to the various health concerns with inorganic farming including the possibility of a chronic kidney disease being associated with chemical fertilizers, many middle aged and experienced farmers displayed skepticism towards these new approaches. Some even resorted to organic farming or utilizing insecticide free fertilizers for their crops. [[238]](#cite_note-auto3-238) In a study conducted by F. Horgan and E. Kudavidanage, the researchers compared crop yields of farmers in Sri Lanka who employed distinct farming techniques including organic farmers who grew traditional varieties, and insecticide-free fertilizer users and pesticide users who grew modern varieties. [[238]](#cite_note-auto3-238) No significant difference was found among the yield productions and in fact, organic farmers and insecticide-free fertilizer users lamented less about insects such as planthoppers as a challenge to their production. Regardless, many farmers continued to use insecticides to avoid the predicted dangers of pests to their crops, and the cheap sale of agrochemicals provided an easy approach to augment crop growth. Additionally, while organic farming has health benefits, it's a strenuous task which requires more man power. [[239]](#cite_note-239) Although that presented a great opportunity for increased employment in Sri Lanka, the economic compensation was not enough to suffice the living expenses of those employed. Thus, most farmers relied on modern methods to run their household, especially after the economic stressors brought on by COVID-19. [[240]](#cite_note-:7-240) However, while Sri Lanka was still facing the new challenges of the pandemic, in the [2019 presidential election](/wiki/2019_Sri_Lankan_presidential_election) campaign, the president, [Gotabaya Rajapaksa](/wiki/Gotabaya_Rajapaksa) proposed a 10-year, national transition to organic farming to declare Sri Lanka as the first nation to be known for its organic produce. [[240]](#cite_note-:7-240) [[241]](#cite_note-241) On April 27, 2021, [[242]](#cite_note-242) the country issued an order prohibiting the import of any inorganic pesticides or fertilizers, creating chaos among farmers. [[243]](#cite_note-243) [[244]](#cite_note-:10-244) [[245]](#cite_note-245) While such a change was made over concerns for the nation's ecosystems and the health of citizens where pesticide poisonings prevailed over other health related deaths, [[246]](#cite_note-246) the precipitous decision was met with criticism from the agriculture industry. This included fears that the mandate would harm the yields of the country's major crops (despite claims to the contrary), that the country would not be able to produce enough organic fertilizer domestically, and organic farming being more expensive and complex than conventional agriculture. [[247]](#cite_note-247) [[244]](#cite_note-:10-244) [[240]](#cite_note-:7-240) To put this into perspective, 7.4% of Sri Lanka's GDP is reliant on agriculture and 30% of citizens work in this sector. [[248]](#cite_note-248) This means that about of its population is dependent on this sector for jobs, making its maintenance highly crucial for the prosperity of the nation's social and economic status. Of special concern was [rice](/wiki/Rice_production_in_Sri_Lanka) and [tea](/wiki/Tea_production_in_Sri_Lanka), which are a staple food and major export respectively. Despite it being a record crop in the first half of 2021, the tea crop began to decline in July of that year. [[240]](#cite_note-:7-240) Rice production fell by 20% over the first six months of the ban, and prices increased by around 50%. Contrary to its past success at [self-sustainability](/wiki/Self-sustainability), the country had to import US$450 million worth of rice to meet domestic demand. [[240]](#cite_note-:7-240) In late August, the government acknowledged the ban had created a critical dependency on supplies of imported organic fertilizers, but by then food prices had already increased twofold in some cases. [[249]](#cite_note-:9-249) In September 2021, the government declared an [economic emergency](/wiki/2019%E2%80%93present_Sri_Lankan_economic_crisis), citing the ban's impact on food prices, as well as inflation from the devaluation of Sri Lankan currency due to the crashing tea industry, and a lack of tourism induced by COVID-19 restrictions. [[250]](#cite_note-250) [[251]](#cite_note-251) [[249]](#cite_note-:9-249) In November 2021, the country partially lifted the ban on inorganic farming for certain key crops such as rubber and tea, and began to offer compensation and subsidies to farmers and rice producers in an attempt to cover losses.
